In addition, they tend to describe outbreaks that are rapidly growing or expanding in range; highly infectious; affecting a large number of people; and caused by novel pathogens against which there is little or no pre-existing immunity.

title: Latent tuberculosis
content: Latent tuberculosis is a condition where an individual is infected with tuberculosis, but the bacteria are inactive and they have no symptoms.

title: Relapsed
content: Relapse is when a disease, or its symptoms, return after a period of recovery. This can require re-treatment.

title: BCG vaccine
content: The BCG vaccine, short for Bacillus Calmette-Guérin vaccine, is a vaccine used against childhood tuberculosis.

title: First line treatment
content: First-line treatment refers to the first and standard treatment recommended for a particular disease.

title: Rifampicin
content: Rifampicin is an antibiotic that is used to treat bacterial infections such as tuberculosis and leprosy. It’s often used as part of the first-line treatment for tuberculosis, along with other antibiotics.

title: Lymphatic system
content: The lymphatic system refers to a particular network of tissues and organs – including lymph nodes, vessels, and fluid – in the body.

title: Global Fund
content: The Global Fund is an international financial organization that provides funding and resources to countries to accelerate the end of AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria as epidemics.

title: USAID
content: The United States Agency for International Development (USAID), is an independent agency of the United States government that administers foreign aid and development assistance to countries around the world.

title: Tuberculosis skin test
content: The tuberculosis skin test often involves the injection of a small amount of substance called PPD tuberculin. This triggers an immune response in people who have been previously infected with TB bacteria.

title: Watt-hour
content: A watt-hour is the energy delivered by one watt of power for one hour. Since one watt is equivalent to one joule per second, a watt-hour is equivalent to 3600 joules of energy.

title: Pull request
content: A pull request is a proposal to merge a set of changes to the project. In a pull request, collaborators can review and discuss the proposed changes.

title: Transit method
content: The transit method detects exoplanets by observing the dimming of a star as an orbiting planet passes between the star and the observer. This transit results in a periodic and slight dip in the star's brightness, which can be measured to infer the planet's presence, size, and orbit.

title: Radial velocity method
content: Also known as Doppler spectroscopy, the radial velocity method measures changes in the star's spectrum due to the gravitational pull of an orbiting planet. As the planet orbits, it causes the star to move in a small orbit in response, which leads to slight shifts in the star's spectral lines due to the Doppler effect. These shifts can reveal the presence of a planet and provide information about its mass and orbit.

title: Microlensing method
content: Gravitational microlensing occurs when the gravitational field of a star (and potentially its planet) acts as a lens, magnifying the light of a background star that happens to pass behind it from the observer's perspective. The presence of a planet can be detected through the specific characteristics of the light curve produced by this event.

title: Equivalent megaton
content: A megaton is the explosive energy released by one million tons of TNT. For comparison, the bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki were 0.015 and 0.021 megatons, respectively.

title: Half-life
content: The “half-life” of a substance refers to the time it takes for that substance to halve in quantity.

title: Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty
content: The treaty’s objective is to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to promote cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and to pursue nuclear and general disarmament.

title: Partial Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty
content: The treaty’s objective is to stop nuclear weapons tests in the atmosphere, in outer space, and under water.

title: Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty
content: The treaty’s objective is to stop nuclear weapons tests in the atmosphere, in outer space, under water, and underground.

title: Nuclear Prohibition Treaty
content: The treaty’s objective is to stop developing, testing, producing, acquiring, possessing, stockpiling, deploying, using, and threatening to use nuclear weapons, as well as assisting other countries in these actions.

title: Country status "Signed" on a treaty
content: This status means that the country accepts a treaty without a legal commitment.

title: Country status "Approved" on a treaty
content: This status means that the country has legally committed to a treaty.

title: Country status "Not signed" on a treaty
content: This status means that the country has neither signed nor committed to a treaty.

title: Country status "Withdrawn" on a treaty
content: This status means that the country has withdrawn from its legal commitment to a treaty.

title: Improved drinking water sources
content: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction, and include: piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

title: Safely managed drinking water services
content: Drinking water from an improved water source that is accessible on premises, available when needed and free from faecal and priority chemical contamination.

title: Basic drinking water services
content: Drinking water from an improved source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.

title: Limited drinking water services
content: Drinking water from an improved source for which collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.

title: Unimproved drinking water services
content: Drinking water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring.

title: Unimproved drinking water services
content: Drinking water directly from a river, dam, lake, pond, stream, canal or irrigation canal.

title: Safely managed sanitation services
content: Use of improved facilities that are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed of in situ or removed and treated offsite.

title: Basic sanitation services
content: Use of improved facilities which are not shared with other households

title: Limited sanitation services
content: Use of improved facilities shared between two or more households.

title: Unimproved sanitation services
content: Use of pit latrines without a slab or platform, hanging latrines or bucket latrines.

title: Unimproved sanitation services
content: Disposal of human faeces in fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, beaches and other open spaces or with solid waste.

title: Cities
content: Cities are settlements that have a population of at least 50,000 inhabitants in contiguous dense grid cells with more than 1,500 inhabitants per km².

title: Towns
content: Towns are settlements that have a population of at least 5,000 inhabitants in contiguous grid cells with a density of at least 300 inhabitants per km².

title: Villages
content: Villages consist mostly of settlements with low-density grid cells with fewer than 300 inhabitants per km².

title: Excellent bathing water quality
content: In order for bathing sites to be classified as ‘excellent’ they must have low levels of both Escherichia coli (E. coli) and intestinal enterococci bacteria, as these are indicative of sewage pollution.

title: The question asked was:
content: For each of the following aspects, indicate how important it is in your life. Would you say it is very important, rather important, not very important or not important at all?

title: The question asked was:
content: I’m going to read out some problems. Please indicate which of the following problems you consider the most serious one for the world as a whole?"

title: The question asked was:
content: "Please tell me for each of the following statements whether you think it can always be justified, never be justified, or something in between, using this card".

title: The question is structured following Shalom H. Schwartz’s questionnaire. Respondents are asked for the degree of identification they have with a hypothetical person described to them:
content: "Now I will briefly describe some people. Using this card, would you please indicate for each description whether that person is very much like you, like you, somewhat like you, a little like you, not like you, or not at all like you?"

title: The question asked was:
content: "On this list are various groups of people. Could you please mention any that you would not like to have as neighbors?".

title: Age of Enlightenment
content: The Age of Enlightenment, rooted in 17th and 18th century Western Europe, celebrated reason and individualism, profoundly reshaping education by promoting literacy and public access to knowledge. This shift laid the groundwork for enlightened, democratic societies in the modern world.

title: Wildfires
content: A wildfire, characterized by its uncontrolled and rapid spread, can occur in various types of vegetation and wildlands, including forests, savannahs, grasslands, and various other vegetation types. These incidents are identified using satellite imagery, which detects thermal anomalies as indicators of active burning areas.

title: Regimes of the World’s regime classification
content: Closed autocracy: citizens do not have the right to choose either the chief executive of the government or the legislature through multi-party elections.

title: Lexical Index regime classification
content: Non-electoral autocracy: citizens do not have the right to elect the chief executive or the legislature one-party autocracy: some citizens have the right to choose the chief executive or the legislature, but only have one choice.

title: Boix et al.’s democracy classification
content: a majority of adult men have the right to choose the chief executive and the legislature in free and fair elections.

title: Boix et al.’s democracy classification (including women’s right to vote)
content: a majority of adult men and women have the right to choose the chief executive and the legislature in free and fair elections.

title: Polity’s regime classification
content: mostly democratic characteristics — open, multi-party, and competitive elections choose chief executive, who faces comprehensive institutional constraints, and political participation is competitive.

title: Freedom House’s regime classification
content: Free country: citizens have many political rights (free and fair elections, political pluralism and participation, functioning government) and civil liberties (freedoms of expression and association, rule of law, personal autonomy).

title: Freedom House’s democracy classification
content: Electoral democracy: citizens have the right to choose chief executive and legislature in broadly free and fair elections and have substantial other political rights and civil liberties.

title: Bertelsmann Transformation Index’s regime classification
content: Consolidating democracy: comprehensive democratic features and minimum democratic characteristics (citizens can choose political leaders in free and fair elections and enjoy freedoms of association, expression and some further civil liberties, political power is separated, and leaders can effectively govern a state that fulfils basic functions).

title: Economist Intelligence Unit’s regime classification
content: Full democracy: comprehensive extent of democracy (extent to which citizens can choose their political leaders in free and fair elections, enjoy civil liberties, prefer democracy over other political systems, can and do participate in politics, and have a functioning government that acts on their behalf), few weaknesses.

title: Episodes of Regime Transformations’ regime classification
content: Autocratizing country: a country that is becoming less electorally democratic, and has seen a substantial decrease in its degree of electoral democracy.

title: Episodes of Regime Transformations’ expanded regime classification
content: Hardening autocracy: an autocracy that is becoming less electorally democratic, and has seen a substantial decrease in its degree of electoral democracy.

title: Manufactured cigarettes
content: Factory-made packeted cigarettes, with or without a filter.

title: Air Quality Guidelines for PM2.5
Cantril Ladder
content: The Cantril Ladder is a metric used to determine individuals life satisfaction, based on the following question:

title: Gender marker change
content: Changing one’s gender in official national documents, such as one’s personal identification document.

title: Opioids
content: Opioid drugs are medications that relieve pain by blocking pain signals in the brain and affecting the nervous system. They can be natural, like morphine, or synthetic, like fentanyl. While they are very effective for severe pain, they can also be highly addictive and dangerous if misused, leading to serious health problems or even death.

title: Influenza
content: Influenza (commonly known as the flu) is a contagious illness caused by the influenza virus.

title: Pertussis
content: Pertussis (commonly known as “whooping cough”) is a highly contagious illness caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis.

title: Biological weapons
content: Biological weapons are organisms or toxins used to cause death or harm through their poisonous properties.

title: Chemical weapons
content: Chemical weapons are chemicals used to cause death or harm through their poisonous properties.

title: Commodity-driven deforestation
content: Large-scale, permanent conversion of forest and shrubland to a nonforest land use such as agriculture (including oil palm), mining, or energy infrastructure.

title: Forestry
content: Temporary loss from plantation and natural forest harvesting, with some deforestation of primary forests.

title: Shifting agriculture
content: Small- to medium-scale forest and shrubland conversion for agriculture that is later abandoned and followed by subsequent forest regrowth.

title: Wildfires
content: Large-scale forest loss resulting from the burning of forest vegetation with no visible human conversion or agricultural activity afterward.

title: Urbanization
content: Forest and shrubland conversion for the expansion and intensification of existing urban centers.

title: Tree cover loss
content: Tree cover loss is the temporary or permanent loss of vegetation greater than five meters in height.

title: Wild woodlands
content: Wild woodlands are characterized by forests and savannas without permanent human populations or intensive land use.

title: Remote woodlands
content: Remote woodlands are characterized by large expanses of forests (woodlands <20% used) located in areas without significant human settlement and infrastructure (<1 person per square kilometer). Due to their remote location, these woodlands often serve as important habitat for rare and endangered species.

title: Residential woodlands
content: Residential woodlands refers to areas of forests or wooded landscapes that are primarily used for residential purposes (10≤ persons per square kilometer < 100), including homes, gardens, and recreational spaces. These areas most likely have been selectively harvested or partially cleared for development, but still retain forest cover and ecological diversity (woodland that is <20% used).

title: Populated woodlands
content: Populated woodlands refers to areas of forest and savanna biomes inhabited by people at relatively low population densities (between 1 and 10 people per square kilometer) and low levels of intensive use (<20% intensively used).

title: Smelting
content: Smelting is a process used to extract metals from their ores. It involves heating the ore to a very high temperature in a furnace. This heat causes the metal inside the ore to separate from other unwanted materials, like rocks and minerals. Often, a substance called a "reducing agent" such as carbon (in the form of coke), is added to help pull the metal out. The result is a more purified form of the metal, which can then be further refined or used to make products.

title: Ore
content: An ore is a type of rock that contains enough of a particular mineral, usually a metal, that it can be mined and processed to extract that metal. For example, iron ore contains iron, and aluminum ore (called bauxite) contains aluminum.

title: Refined production
content: Refined production is the process of taking raw materials, such as metals extracted from ores, and purifying them to achieve a higher quality or more usable form. After metals are initially extracted from ore through processes like smelting, they often contain impurities or are not in the ideal form for manufacturing. Refining involves further processing these metals to remove impurities and adjust their composition to meet specific standards.

title: Mineral reserve
content: A mineral reserve is the amount of a mineral that can be mined and used profitably with current technology and market conditions. There are two types:

title: Established alien species
content: An established alien species is a species that has been introduced to an area outside of it’s native range and has produce a viable self-sustaining population which may have spread.

title: Native range
content: The native, or natural, range of a species is the geographical area where it has historically occurred, without human intervention.

title: Antimony
content: Antimony is a metal that is mixed with others to form alloys to be used in pipes, motors, car parts, and batteries. It’s also used in the textile industry, where it’s added to plastics, rubber, and other materials to make them less likely to catch fire.

title: Barite
content: Barite is a mineral that is used in construction, oil and gas refining and drilling, as a radiation shield in medical technologies such as X-rays, and in industries such as paints, ceramics, and glass.

title: Bauxite
content: Bauxite is the primary source of aluminum. It’s refined into aluminum oxide and then smelted into aluminum.

title: Beryllium
content: Beryllium is a material that’s used in alloys with copper or nickel. It’s used in applications such as electronics, in the car industry for ignition and brake systems, and in military defense.

title: Bismuth
content: Bismuth is a metal that is often paired with other metals to form alloys. It’s found in electronic components such as semiconductors, and used in fuses and sprinkler systems. Bismuth compounds are also used in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals.

title: Boron
content: Boron is a material that is often used in industrial products such as glass and fiberglass, and in metal alloys and semiconductors. Boron compounds are often used in medical technologies, fertilizers, and pesticides.

title: Cadmium
content: Cadmium is a metal that is used in alloys with steel and iron, in batteries, solar panels, and pigments. It’s often used to protect other metals from corrosion.

title: Cobalt
content: Cobalt is used in a number of industries: consumer electronics (it’s in most mobile phones and laptops), catalysts for the oil industry, resistant metal alloys, and ceramics.

title: Coltan
content: Coltan is a mineral that has electrical properties that make it very valuable in consumer electronic products, such as mobile phones and laptops.

title: Feldspar
content: Feldspar is a key source of alumina, which is used in glassmaking, ceramics, and as fillers in paints and adhesives.

title: Fluorspar
content: Fluorspar is a mineral that’s used in aluminum production, uranium fuel for nuclear power, and in steel and iron making. It’s also used in glass, refrigeration, and in lithium-ion batteries, where it’s a key component in cathodes.

title: Gallium
content: Galium is a metal that is used in electronic components such as semiconductors, electrical circuits and LEDs. It’s also used in thermometers, and medical technologies such as cancer screening.

title: Garnet
content: Garnet is a mineral that’s used as an abrasive in products such as sandpaper, and for industrial cleaning applications.

title: Germanium
content: Germanium is a material that’s used in consumer electronics — such as laptops and mobile phones — for transistors and semiconductors. It’s also used in fiber optics, camera lenses, and solar panel manufacturing.

title: Graphite
content: Graphite is a mineral that is used in batteries, steelmaking, lubricants, and pencils.

title: Gypsum
content: Gypsum is a mineral that’s used in agriculture for fertilizers. It’s also widely used in construction for plaster and wallboard products; its resistance to fire and sound-proofing make it ideal for construction.

title: Mica
content: Mica is a mineral that’s used in electronics for cable insulation, in the car industry for brake linings, and in cosmetics such as skin care and facial products.

title: Molybdenum
content: Molybdenum has a very high electrical conductivity but expands very little when exposed to heat. It is used in alloys, particularly with steel, for applications such as electric motors, and filaments in light bulbs, and in aircraft.

title: Niobium
content: Niobium is used in alloys, such as stainless steel. That means it’s used in many products that rely on steel, as well as being used in superconducting magnets, medical technologies, and aerospace engines.

title: Strontium
content: Strontium is a metal that’s used in electrical products such as televisions, in fireworks, flares and paints, and in some medical technologies and treatments.

title: Tantalum
content: Tantalum is a metal that is very resistant to corrosion and high temperatures. This makes it ideal for applications in consumer electronic devices such as phones and laptops; in medical technologies, and in chemical industries.

title: Tungsten
content: Tungsten is a mineral that is used in consumer electronics, semiconductors, medical equipment, light bulbs, furnaces and other applications where low thermal expansion is useful.

title: Vanadium
content: Vanadium is a metal that is used in steel alloys, in superconducting magnets, dyes, ceramics and some types of batteries.

title: Zirconium
content: Zirconium is a material that’s used as shielding in nuclear power plants, in chemical industries for catalysts and pigments, and in various applications in medical technologies and cosmetics.

title: Hafnium
content: Hafnium is a metal that’s used as shielding in nuclear power plants. It’s also mixed with other metals to form alloys that are used in wind turbine blades, gas turbines and the aerospace industry.

title: Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS)
content: This scenario projects the future energy system based on the continuation of current policy settings.

title: Announced Pledges Scenario (APS)
content: This scenario assumes that governments fully implement all their announced climate commitments, including long-term net-zero targets and pledges in nationally determined contributions (NDCs).

title: Net Zero Emissions by 2050 (NZE) Scenario
content: This scenario outlines a pathway where the global energy sector achieves net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050.

title: Mammography
content: An imaging test that uses X-rays to detect abnormalities in breast tissue, often used to screen for breast cancer.

title: Pap smear
content: A medical test that collects cells from the cervix to check for signs of cervical cancer or abnormal cell changes.

title: Human papillomavirus (HPV)
content: A common virus that can infect the skin, genitals, mouth or throat. It spreads through skin-to-skin contact, including sexual activity.

title: Colonoscopy
content: A medical exam where a long, flexible tube with a camera is used to look inside the colon for signs of cancer, polyps, or other abnormalities.

title: Non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC)
content: Non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) refers to skin cancers aside from melanoma.

title: Benign
content: A term used to describe a tumor or growth that is not cancerous and doesn’t spread to other parts of the body.

title: Malignant
content: A term for cancerous growths or tumors that can invade nearby tissues and spread to other parts of the body.

title: Leukemia
content: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming tissues, like the bone marrow, leading to the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells.

title: Lymphoma
content: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which helps protect the body from infections.

title: Carcinogen
content: A substance or exposure that can cause cancer by damaging DNA or triggering abnormal cell growth.

title: Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori)
content: A type of bacteria that infects the stomach lining, and can cause stomach ulcers, long-term inflammation, and stomach cancer.

title: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
content: A group of lung diseases, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis, that cause breathing difficulties due to long-term damage to the lungs.

title: Remittance corridor
content: A remittance corridor refers to the flow of money between two countries, specifically from the country where the migrant is working to their home country.

title: Kaposi’s sarcoma
content: A rare cancer that causes patches of abnormal tissue to grow under the skin, in the lining of the mouth, or in other organs, often associated with a weakened immune system.

title: Myeloma
content: A type of cancer that starts in the plasma cells, a kind of white blood cell that helps the body fight infections by producing antibodies.

title: A type of skin cancer that starts in “melanocytes”, which are cells that give skin its color.
content: Melanoma is more likely than other skin cancers to be serious, and can spread to other parts of the body if not caught early.

title: A system that continuously tracks information on individuals residing in a country, such as births, deaths, marriages, and changes in address.
content: Unlike a population census, which collects data on the entire population at a specific point in time (usually every 5 or 10 years), a population register is updated in real time. Most countries do not keep population registers.

title: Hectare
content: A hectare is a unit of area used to measure land surface. It corresponds to 10,000 square meters, or a square piece of land that’s 100 meters on each side.

title: Anemia
content: Anemia is a condition where someone has fewer red blood cells, or lower levels of hemoglobin in their blood cells. This is important because either deficit affects our ability to carry oxygen around the body. That means tissues are lacking in oxygen and can’t function properly.

title: Antimicrobials
content: Antimicrobial are a type of medicine that kill microorganisms. They can be grouped according to the microorganism they primarily act against. For example, antibiotics are used against bacteria, antifungals are used against fungi, antivrials are used against viruses and antiparasites are used against parasites.

title: Penicillins
content: Penicillins are a class of antibiotics that kill bacteria by disrupting their cell walls.

title: Sulfonamides
content: Sulfonamides are a class of antibiotics that prevent bacteria from growing by blocking their ability to make folic acid, which they need to survive.

title: Tetracyclines
content: Tetracyclines are a class of broad-spectrum antibiotics that stop bacteria from making proteins needed for their survival.

title: Macrolides
content: Macrolides are a class of antibiotics that work by stopping bacteria from making proteins.

title: (Fluoro-)quinolones
content: Quinolones are a class of antibiotics that kill bacteria by interfering with their ability to replicate DNA, which is essential for their survival and reproduction.

title: Carbapenems
content: Carbapenems are a class of beta-lactam antibiotics with a broad-spectrum of activity, which includes many Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, and anaerobic bacteria.

title: Monobactams
content: Monobactams are a class of antibiotics that target bacteria with specific cell walls.

title: Lipopeptides
content: Lipopeptides are a class of antibiotics that disrupt bacterial cell membranes, causing the bacteria to die.

title: Reserve antibiotics
content: Reserve antibiotics refer to antibiotics kept as a last resort for treating serious infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria. They are used sparingly to preserve their effectiveness.

title: Access antibiotics
content: Access antibiotics are antibiotics with a narrow spectrum of activity, which are generally cheaper, have fewer side effects, and are less likely to contribute to resistance. They are recommended as first-line treatments for many common bacterial infections.

title: Watch antibiotics
content: Watch antibiotics refer to antibiotics generally have a higher risk of promoting resistance and require careful monitoring. They are recommended to be kept for more specific or severe infections, in hospitals.

title: Mass drug administration
content: Mass drug administration refers to providing a medicine to entire communities to prevent or treat a disease, whether or not people have been diagnosed with it.

title: Sepsis
content: Sepsis is a serious condition where the body’s response to an infection in the blood causes widespread inflammation, which can lead to organ damage and death. It requires urgent medical attention.

title: Antibiotic resistance
content: Antibiotic resistance is when bacteria have evolved to survive antibiotics that used to kill them.

title: Syphilis
content: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.

title: Chlamydia
content: Chlamydia is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Chlamydia trachomatis. It can remain “silent” in the body for many years before causing symptoms.

title: Streptococcal infections
content: Different types of Streptococcus bacteria can cause a range of conditions, from mild to life-threatening.

title: Scarlet fever
content: Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (also known as group A Streptococcus).

title: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
content: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus refers to a type of bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus) that has become resistant to the antibiotic methicillin, which is an antibiotic in the penicillin drug class.

title: Klebsiella pneumoniae (K. pneumoniae)
content: Klebsiella pneumoniae is a bacterium that can cause pneumonia, bloodstream infections, or meningitis. Some strains are resistant to multiple antibiotics, making them difficult to treat.

title: Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis)
content: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the bacterium that causes tuberculosis, a serious lung disease.

title: Western Europe in the Maddison Project Database.
content: Western Europe as defined by the Maddison Project Database includes the following countries: Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom.

title: Antibiotic stewardship
content: Antibiotic stewardship refers to programs and practices aimed at improving the use of antibiotics to ensure they are prescribed only when necessary and in the correct dose, duration, and type.

title: Broad-spectrum antibiotics
content: “Broad-spectrum” antibiotics refer to antibiotics that are effective against a wide range of bacteria, including both gram-positive and gram-negative types.

title: Beta-lactams
content: A large class of antibiotics that kill bacteria by targeting their cell walls.

title: Gram-positive
content: Gram-positive bacteria have thick cell walls that are mostly made of a substance called peptidoglycan.

title: Gram-negative
content: Gram-negative bacteria have thinner cell walls surrounded by an outer membrane.

title: Development Assistance Committee (DAC) countries
content: The DAC is a forum under the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Its 32 members (including the European Union) coordinate policies and track official development assistance.

title: Group A Streptococcus (GAS)
content: Group A Streptococcus (GAS) refers to Streptococcus pyogenes bacteria, which can live on the skin or in the throat, often without causing symptoms.

title: Staphylococcus aureus
content: Staphylococcus aureus refers to a species of bacteria commonly found on the skin and in the nose of healthy individuals.

title: Actinomycetes
content: Actinomycetes are a group of soil-dwelling bacteria that are prolific producers of antibiotics.

title: Delivery
content: A delivery refers to the birth event in which one or more babies are born, whether it’s a single baby (singleton birth) or multiple babies (twin or more).

title: Singleton
content: A singleton refers to a single baby born in one delivery, as opposed to multiple babies (like twins or triplets).

title: Age-specific fertility rate
content: The fertility rate (number of births per woman) in a specific age group.

title: In vitro fertilization (IVF)
content: In vitro fertilization (IVF) is a medical procedure where an egg is fertilized by sperm outside the body, in a laboratory, and then the resulting embryo is implanted into the uterus to help achieve pregnancy.

title: Childbearing years
content: Childbearing years (also called “reproductive years”) refer to the age range during which women are biologically most likely to conceive and give birth.

title: World Bank poverty projections scenarios
content: The World Bank Poverty, Prosperity, and Planet Report provides a range of projected scenarios for poverty trends. These rely on varying assumptions about economic growth rates and/or inequality reduction to explore different potential outcomes under different economic conditions.

title: Bilateral aid
content: Bilateral aid is financial assistance provided directly by one country to another, rather than through international organizations.

title: Multilateral aid
content: Multilateral aid involves contributions from countries to international organizations, such as the UN or World Bank, which fund developmental programs.

title: Battery cell
content: A battery cell is the basic unit of a battery that stores and releases energy through electrochemical reactions.

title: G7
content: The G7 is a forum of seven of the world's major advanced economies: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

title: Lithium-ion battery
content: A lithium-ion battery is a rechargeable battery that stores energy by moving lithium ions between the anode and cathode during charging and discharging. It is widely used in electric vehicles, consumer electronics, and energy storage systems.

title: FTSE 100
content: The FTSE 100 is an index that represents the 100 largest companies listed on the London Stock Exchange (LSE), based on market capitalization. The index is used as a benchmark to track the performance of these large, publicly traded companies, which span a range of industries, including financial services, consumer goods, and energy. The FTSE 100 is often used to gauge the overall health of the UK stock market and the broader economy.

title: Oil rents
content: Oil rents are the difference between the value of crude oil production at regional prices and the total costs of production. These rents are used to calculate the contribution of oil profits to a country’s GDP. Countries with large oil industries often see a significant portion of their GDP from oil rents, which reflect earnings above the cost of extracting the resource.

title: Purchasing Power Standard (PPS)
content: The Purchasing Power Standard (PPS) is an artificial currency unit developed by Eurostat to compare economic data across countries by adjusting for differences in price levels. It enables meaningful comparisons of indicators like energy prices, reflecting the relative purchasing power of different countries.
